etymology.description: 月(肉) (ròu, "meat") + 却(卻) (què, phonetic) = bodily part + phonetic indication -> foot
etymology.interpretation: The character 脚(腳) (jiǎo, "foot") combines 月(肉) (ròu, "meat") as a semantic component to indicate it is a part of the body, with 却(卻) (què) as a phonetic component to suggest pronunciation.
etymology.simplification: 脚(腳) was derived by reducing the complexity of 卻 in traditional form to 却 in simplified form, retaining phonetic elements while easing writing.

examples.chinese: 我散步时(我散步時)，脚感觉很舒服(腳感覺很舒服)。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ sànbù shí, jiǎo gǎnjué hěn shūfú.
examples.english: When I take a walk, my foot feels very comfortable.

examples.chinese: 他不小心踢到了桌子(他不小心踢到了桌子)，脚受了伤(腳受了傷)。
examples.pinyin: Tā bù xiǎoxīn tī dào le zhuōzi, jiǎo shòu le shāng.
examples.english: He accidentally kicked the table and injured his foot.

examples.chinese: 运动时(運動時)，脚会流汗(腳會流汗)。
examples.pinyin: Yùndòng shí, jiǎo huì liú hàn.
examples.english: During exercise, the foot starts to sweat.
